answers.text:
Allison,
The best example of an Excel-based dashboard that I've seen was developed by the City of Cartersville, GA.  The developer was Tom Quist.  At the time, Tom worked for the city, but I believe he has since started his own consulting firm.  Here is a link to Tom's dashboard, which was posted to the KN back in 2012:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/303799/Sample_Performance_Management_Dashboard

answers.author: Thomas Quist
answers.text:
Allison,
First, I'd like to tell you that I think you are smart to pursue an Excel-based dashboard.  Though I haven't really explored commercial software packages in a while, I have never seen anything that I was that impressed with (a vast majority of the products seemed to value style over substance:  "Wow!  Cool 3D speedometer").  Not to mention, the cost is also usually pretty significant.  Depending on the nature of your performance measurement program, it may be hard to find a software package that "fits" with your program.  Considerations may include 1) where your data is stored, 2) how it is collected, 3) how granular your data is, 4) how often you collect it, 5) how sophisticated your analysis needs are, and so on.  Using Excel allows you to the possibility of creating a tailored solution for your organizational needs and capabilities, and it uses a software platform that is ubiquitous.
All that said, Excel can be challenging to work with.  Most jurisdictions likely don't have someone in-house with the skills required to develop and maintain a functional dashboard in Excel.  Maybe YOU could be that person :)
Before I developed my first automated performance dashboard, I considered myself to be comfortable with Excel, but not necessarily an expert.  It took a lot of time and energy to develop the skills that would allow the creation of functional, automated, dynamic, and interactive dashboards.  However, there are some basic skills that you could likely master fairly quickly that would allow you to build some straightforward and basic dashboards.  Here are the topics I would recommend studying:
1)  Dynamic Charts (some associated topics below)
     -Named Ranges
     -Index Function
     -Offset Function
     -Match Function
2)  Data Visualization Best Practices
There are lots of great resources out there to help you along the way.  Here are just a couple of my favorites:
For all things Excel:
-Chandoo (http://chandoo.org/wp/)
-Excel Hero (http://www.excelhero.com/blog/)
-Jon Peltier (http://peltiertech.com/)
For Data Visualization
-Stephen Few (http://www.perceptualedge.com/blog/)
Good luck!
Tom
P.S. DON!  Thanks for the shout out!
